text: Thank you, Mr. Page. It is an honor to talk to our board, especially during School Board Appreciation Month. It was in 1995 that the National School Board Association declared the first such occasion. And I only can say what took so long.  I think it was President John F. Kennedy who said, our progress as a nation can be no swifter than our progress in education. And here in Albemarle County, our progress has been in good hands. You have made so many impactful policies and programs possible, starting with where I am here tonight, a student representative on the school board. As students, we are grateful that in your hands  You have established a direct link between us. We are deeply appreciative for your commitment to all families that our educators and support staff will know every student. Tonight we are going to hear a little bit about how  You have made a difference in the lives of our students. The addition of social and emotional counselors in every single one of our schools. If our schools are to fuel the progress of our nation, every student must be ready to learn at their full potential. You have hope to ensure that this will help happen for every student in every school. At no time have you been called upon  to make more important decisions than you have been during this two-year pandemic.  You have kept us safe and you have created learning environments that meet the theme this year of School Board Appreciation Month in Virginia, building the future of public education. We see that work going on in the classrooms, hallways, labs, libraries, and in the portfolios of every student. And it starts right here in these meetings and through your actions. You're not just building the future of public education,  You are leading us to a better future, a more inclusive one, a more exciting, more rewarding one. And it starts with supporting the most basic and important needs of students, their social and emotional well-being, their confidence, their readiness to learn.  On this note, it is my privilege to introduce Miles Nelson from our Student Services Department, who will introduce you to some of the remarkable professionals you have put into our schools. Mr. Nelson.
speaker: elizabethalbarran

text: Thank you, Elizabeth, for that wonderful introduction.  I'm very excited to be here tonight, and as Elizabeth said, February is School Board Appreciation Month, and I feel very honored to be here before you tonight to say thank you for everything that you do. And as we talk about appreciation, I would like to say thank you for the wisdom the School Board has shown in supporting children's mental health. Recently, the Surgeon General, in a joint statement with the American Academy of Pediatrics, the American Academy of Child and Adolescent  psychiatry, and the Children's Hospital Association have all recently issued advisories for the current crisis of students' mental health. This year, as Elizabeth has stated, we have added the support of our SEL counselors to our schools to extend the support of school-based mental health services we can provide children. Tonight, I have with me a few of them, our SEL counselors that have been lifting up this work and supporting children's mental health. I'm very excited to introduce Juliana Vining from Curzé Elementary,  Summer Popolo from Albemarle, and Bree Lundgren from Monticello. Bree has a background in youth diversion, individual and family counseling, and most recently as a mental health crisis evaluator in the emergency room at UVA Hospital. She's a very qualified school-based mental health professional that will be able to give an example of how our SEL counselors can and have supported children in accessing mental health services within our schools.  Very briefly, I would like to talk about our schools and national trends and children's mental health. So as we all know, schools tend to be the center for our communities and we want to uplift our children to the best of our ability. With that being said, children who have a diagnosable mental health disorder.  often do not receive mental health services. So much so that 80% of children with diagnosable mental health disorders do not receive mental health services. However, I would like to highlight that out of 20% of children that are receiving mental health services, that 70 to 80% of the children's first entry into mental health services are within schools with individuals just like Juliana, Summer, and Bri.  At this time, I would like to turn it over to Brie Lundgren to give an example of how many of our SEL counselors are supporting the mental health of our children in Albemarle County Public Schools.
speaker: milesnelson

text: Hi, good evening. I'm Brie and thanks for having me tonight. Like Miles said, I came to Monticello as an LPC resident with a background in youth diversion, individual and family counseling, and most recently as a  mental health crisis at the ER at UVA hospital. A major motivator for me seeking this position was due to the increasing number of youth with mental health crises that I assisted in the ER. The CARES grant provided a lot of leeway for each SEL counselor to determine our own methodologies  to meet the specific needs of the individual schools we are in. At MHS, it has allowed me to have an open door policy that has meant me having over 600 interactions already this school year, including parents and teachers as well as students. It is amazing how sometimes just a few minutes of listening to someone  Acknowledging and processing their emotions or mediating a miscommunication between students can be all that it takes to keep things running smoothly. I have one story that I would like to share with you today about a student at Monticello I will call Mary.  Mary is not someone most people would ever suspect is struggling. In fact, she is one of the ones that teachers rarely worry about because she is so on the ball. Straight A's, accepted by four universities, well-spoken, well-mannered, and she comes from a solid home with loving parents and good resources. Three months ago, Mary was referred to me by her school counselor who felt that something more was going on with the student.  Over regular weekly meetings, Mary and I built a relationship based on trust. She was able to confide her anxiety and depression issues to me, and we were working through them slowly. Two weeks ago, Mary came to me and confided that she was going to kill herself.  I knew her and I knew she was serious and I immediately brought her parents in and I assisted them with the necessary protocols and Mary was admitted and treated and she's now back at school this week. I was able to act as the coordinator between the parents, the teachers, her counselors and her doctors to develop an action plan to make sure she stays in a good place and continues the  positive trajectory she is on. She knows I'm here for her and has stated that knowing I am there in the school if she stumbles is partly what gives her the strength to make it through the school day. And while this is an extreme case, she is but one of four suicide referrals that our team has processed this year.  We live in very scary times and the need for mental health professionals in the school has never been greater. Mary is moving forward and I truly believe she will get through this and be fine. I'm telling you her story with not only the full permission of her and her parents, but with their encouragement and endorsement for all the SEL counselors do.  Having me at the school is the security Mary needs to continue to ride herself, and it gives me immense satisfaction to know I am making a real difference in hers and other students' lives every day. While this is an extreme example to showcase, it is important to note that by being there before it gets this far is how we can prevent these situations in the first place. Thank you for your time.

text: Thank you, Mr. Page. Just a couple of announcements. First, I want to really thank Myles and Bree, Juliana and Summer for being here tonight to share the story of our social-emotional counselors. You're doing wonderful work and it's highly impactful.  and we are so glad that you're out in schools working with our students and families and with our staff. Thank you. I wanna thank KTEC director, Stephanie Carter, the lab school principal, Chad Ratliff, Red Hill Elementary School, Nancy McCullen, Walton Middle School principal, Josh Walton, and Monticello High School principal, Rick Verhoevac for coming to the meeting tonight. If y'all wanna turn on your cameras,  briefly just so we can all say hi to you and thank you all for the outstanding work that you are doing, keeping our schools moving forward. We really appreciate it and we're glad you can join us tonight. I did get an opportunity to get out and visit Albemarle High School on Monday. I had a great visit with Mr. Bonham and was able to visit several classrooms. One of the things he told me at the outset of the visit was based on the,  really challenging attendance numbers, some instability at the school with students and some other issues at the beginning of the year, the staff rallied together  and really reconfigured their schedule so that they have their intervention period at the beginning of the day, creating what probably a lot of us would remember as a homeroom period. The staff all pitched in, so everybody has a homeroom, and so they don't have more than 17 students each so that they can build relationships. Students got to pick some teachers they wanted to be with.  or to have a say in the teacher they wanted to be with. And the teacher also had the opportunity to request students. They hand-scheduled the students. And so what they're looking to see is reduced tardiness to the academic classes because students come in for their homeroom first. text: Hi, my name is Nick Macy. I live in the Whitehall district. I'd like to express my support as well for continued universal masking in our schools as the current legal process plays out. And my thanks to ACPS for making a responsible decision, which is widely supported by the community. Let's be clear. I'm tired of COVID as is probably everyone here.  Clearly, the transition from pandemic to endemic was always destined to be messy given the current polarized climate. However, the virus doesn't care about our politics or if we're tired. The way in which we approach the virus has to be rational, measured, and based on science. While the situation is improving, the current surge is not yet over. Local case counts and hospitalizations are trending downward, but they remain similar to the prior peak from last winter. Having a reasonable discussion about off-ramps to end masking is one thing.  But actually taking that off ramp right now while driving 90 miles an hour is something completely different. Hopefully the current surge continues to recede. However, the one predictable aspect of COVID thus far has been its unpredictability. As a county and as a state, we need to make sure that we are prepared to deal with future challenges. There may be a variant less affected by vaccines or that is more detrimental to children. It would be foolish to institute policies now, which would permanently disallow universal masking in schools in the future, as is currently being discussed in our state.  In summary, we need to be careful about the timing of eliminating universal masking, and if there is a change in policy at some point, we need to be careful that we don't prohibit universal masking should it be needed again in the future in order to preserve in-person learning. Thank you again to our school board for doing what has been necessary to make sure that students, families, and teachers in our community are safe. Thank you.

text: Thank you so much, Dr. Haas. Good evening, board members.  My name is Jasmine Fernandez. Over the past two and a half years, I've had the great pleasure to oversee the name review process. Tonight, you will hear from the Broaduswood Committee. This is the sixth school that has been under review, and I'm particularly excited for you to hear about how they have engaged the community, especially the students.  Just quickly, I wanted to remind you all of the directive that you gave to the superintendent. All schools in the division named after individuals will undergo a review process to ensure those designations align with the division's values. And as you know, our four newly approved values include equity, excellence, family and community, and wellness.  In addition to our division values, we are guided by three intentions throughout the review process. Reflection, accessibility, and inclusion of all voices. The purpose of the review process is to reflect on the past, but also reaffirm our school's values and aspirations. Through the use of QR codes, surveys, community meetings, social media, and emails,  we've been able to offer different modes of participation throughout this process. And as with every process, we value and actively work to hear from all stakeholders, including first and foremost, our students, our staff, our families, and our community members.  As a reminder in the past the board has taken action on five names, I think it's important to remind you and the broader public that just because a name is under review. It does not automatically mean that the name will be changed as evidenced by us retaining Virginia or Murray's name.  In fact, moving forward, schools whose names are retained will receive some support so that they can continue to further commemorate the achievements of the individual and continue to share their school's history with future students and families for years to come. And with that, it is now my pleasure to turn it over to Principal Morris.

text: Hi, my name is Katie bro and I'm the talent development resource teacher and interventionist abroad as good, along with Ray crow back I am co chair of our schools name review committee, and an effort to share this process with our community. We utilize multiple modes of communication and participation.  For each survey, flyers were distributed to families, to staff, and to popular places in our community that contained information about the process, as well as QR codes which enabled timely participation. The codes were posted outside of our building and our family drop off and pickup areas.  Mrs. Morris ensured that families were aware of each survey and step of the name review process, including upcoming community meetings by frequently including messages and our weekly emails to families and notices to staff. Further, we had support from central office with regards to routine press releases and social media posts. A comprehensive webpage for Broaduswood Elementary School was added to the county school name review webpage, and we were able to share similar information on our own school's website.  While the current policy only requires two community surveys, our committee felt strongly about including an additional survey to determine how much our community already knew about the name review process, as well as the history of Broadus-Irawood. This first survey showed that a majority of respondents did consider themselves familiar with the life and career of Broadus-Irawood, as well as the Admiral County Public School values and the Broaduswood Elementary School guiding principles.  Additional information on each of these surveys, as well as the press releases community meeting recordings and information about our committee can still be found on the school name review web page and when reviewing the survey data. Please keep in mind that a majority of our approximately 250 students were included in each survey.  We feel grateful for the amount of public participation in this process and for having the opportunity to incorporate their feedback. Thanks to the consistent communication that we were able to share with our community throughout the process, we were able to engage the public through our two community meetings, which were live streamed and recorded, and messages sent to the school name review email address.  Speaking on behalf of the committee, we were energized to hear the public's opinion, both through the email messages and during community meetings. text: Eddie, thanks so much for humanizing this process with Ben's insightful remarks. I'm Karen Waters Wicks, Community Education Coordinator for Albemarle County Public Schools, and I served on the committee. I was better with my Zoom during the meetings, I promise. Jody Weber, Charles Crenshaw, and I focused on compiling historical research on B.I. Woods, which is how he signed the minutes book when he was serving as the school board chair.  As part of the review process, the committee looked at all of the emails from the public, as well as letters to the editor published in the Daily Progress. We're grateful to Marta Ramsey and Bill Schmidt, two of Mr. Woods' descendants, who shared their family remembrances with us, and we reviewed newspaper articles, school board minutes, and compiled a list of secondary resources.  We're also appreciative of the work of local historian and journalist Jordy Yeager and descendant researcher Dr. Shelly Murphy from the University of Virginia, who provided us with a history of Mr. Woods family land and land holdings. The materials we gathered present a rich picture of Mr. Woods and are available on the website.  We learned that Mr. Woods was very committed to public education, serving for 36 years on the Albemarle County School Board, which met at 11 a.m. on the third Wednesday of the month, and they were paid a grand sum of $5 per diem, according to the school board minutes from September 5th, 1922. His roots in the county date back to his great-grandfather, who came here from Maryland and established the family farm.  Although our research indicates he may have benefited from his ancestors holdings of enslaved individuals, having been born after the Civil War, Mr would had no involvement in this, and further chose to gift a significant portion of the family's property to the school system.  Additionally, school board records indicate he was supportive of local schools, particularly rural schools, and frequently voted in favor of building and supporting the quote unquote colored schools to use the vernacular of the times, and he was commended upon his retirement by the supervisor for Negro education in 1931. And that is the image of the letter that you see on the screen.  In addition to a service to our schools he served as a director of the People's National Bank. He was a forest warden and served as deputy commissioner of the revenue. When he was tragically killed as a result of being hit by a taxi cab while visiting his daughter at George Washington University in Washington DC at the age of 68. Mr. Woods funeral drew a crowd of 1000 people.  It was gratifying for me and for the rest of the committee to have the opportunity to learn about this man whose name has essentially become a place. And with that, I'm going to turn it over to Ray, and he can tell you more about how he and the rest of the faculty and staff at Broadus Wood Elementary engage the children in participating in our process and having fun learning about Mr. Wood.

text: Thank you, Karen.  Members of the board, Dr. Haas, thank you for giving us this time to speak about the school name review for Broadduswood Elementary. I am Raymond Krobach, school librarian and co-facilitator of the Name Review Advisory Committee. I have a few things to show you. I know you can't see the details, but these are Bobcat prints. This one says, you will always be a Bobcat. Love it.  Have fun, that's what being a Bobcat is. This is the best school. We are Bobcats forever. A Bobcat is kind, safe, respectful, responsible, and most of all, a Bobcat. I love this school. Once a Bobcat, always a Bobcat.  These are Bobcat Pride paw prints created by current students at Broadus Wood Elementary, part of a culminating activity for the name review process. Students were engaged in this process concurrently throughout. Mrs. Breaux, myself, and the committee were committed to ensuring the students' experience was both informative and engaging.  This process started at the beginning of the school year when every class had a lesson on the history of Broadduswood Elementary and who Broaddus Ira Wood was. Students participated in lessons that implemented history and research skills. We had a then and now lesson to where we compared what school was like then and now at Broadduswood. The students couldn't believe that horse stables were part of the original school.  The second part focused on lessons that attempted to answer the questions, what's behind a name? Who are we? And what it means to be a Bobcat. The culminating activity included a school-wide virtual assembly that empowered the students to vote on the name and created paw prints for a future mural that symbolizes Bobcat pride. As for the recommendation,  Based on the research, public comments and survey results, the committee voted for Broadus Wood Elementary. This was based on Broadus Ira Woods contributions that align with the division's values and the school's guiding principles. Some examples include how he advanced education opportunities for African American and rural students.  The committee took into consideration all stakeholders' voices, particularly the votes of alumni and current students. The majority of the students, nearly 68%, voted to retain the name after learning about Broadus-Irewood's service and involvement in the community. If the name is retained, the school is looking to commemorate the process and Broadus-Wood's contributions via the school webpage and a forthcoming ceremony. Thank you again.
